rounds.observation:
Welcome to the Trading Arena! You are Player 0 in this competitive resource exchange game.
Your goal is to maximize your wealth by strategically trading resources with your opponent.
Your current resource portfolio includes:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 22   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 14   Value: 12
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 11   Value: 14
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 18   Value: 22
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 11   Value: 34
Each turn provides an opportunity to negotiate with your trading partner.
To interact effectively, use these action commands:
  - '[Offer: 4 Wood, 1 Brick -> 2 Ore, 3 Wheat]': Format - [Offer: What_You_Give -> What_You_Want]
  - '[Accept]': Use this to accept any pending trade proposal.
  - '[Deny]': Use this to reject any pending trade proposal (this is the default response).
This trading session will continue for exactly 10 rounds.

Welcome to the Trading Arena! You are Player 1 in this competitive resource exchange game.
Your goal is to maximize your wealth by strategically trading resources with your opponent.
Your current resource portfolio includes:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 12   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 13   Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 12   Value: 17
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 24   Value: 29
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 6    Value: 39
Each turn provides an opportunity to negotiate with your trading partner.
To interact effectively, use these action commands:
  - '[Offer: 4 Wood, 1 Brick -> 2 Ore, 3 Wheat]': Format - [Offer: What_You_Give -> What_You_Want]
  - '[Accept]': Use this to accept any pending trade proposal.
  - '[Deny]': Use this to reject any pending trade proposal (this is the default response).
This trading session will continue for exactly 10 rounds.
 Player 0 made the following offer to Player 1: Offered items: 5 Wheat, 2 Wood -> Requested items: 1 Ore, 1 Sheep
rounds.response:
Let me evaluate Player 0’s offer first.

Offer on the table
- They give: 5 Wheat + 2 Wood  
  5×6 + 2×8 = 30 + 16 = 46 value points  

- They want: 1 Ore + 1 Sheep  
  1×39 + 1×17 = 56 value points  

Net: I would give 56 value and only receive 46 → a –10 value disadvantage to me.

As a profit-seeking Player 1, my incentive is to reject any trade that makes me poorer.

Therefore:

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me quickly crunch the numbers on the new proposal.

Player 0 is offering: 4 Wheat (4×6 = 24 value) and 2 Wood (2×8 = 16 value) → total 40 value.  
Player 0 is requesting: 1 Ore (39 value) and 1 Sheep (17 value) → total 56 value.

Net value exchanged:
- I give away goods worth 56
- I receive goods worth 40  
- Net loss to me ≈ 16 value

That’s still unfavorable. I’ll reject.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me evaluate the current situation.

Current resources and values (useful for decision-making)

Resource | My Qty | My Value | Offered/Relevant
Wheat    | 12     | 6        | 3 offered
Wood     | 13     | 8        | —
Sheep    | 12     | 17       | —
Brick    | 24     | 29       | 1 offered
Ore      | 6      | 39       | 1 requested

Opponent’s latest offer:  
Give me 3 Wheat + 1 Brick → Receive 1 Ore

Valuation check

- 3 Wheat = 3×6 = 18 value  
- 1 Brick = 29 value  
Total being given = 47 value  

- 1 Ore = 39 value  

Net value change for me = 39 – 47 = –8  
This is unfavorable; the opponent is extracting 8 PV of surplus from me. I already have 6 Ore, and with so few (6 Ore vs my other plentiful goods), keeping Ore is important.

Therefore I definitely reject. However, opponents usually do not keep making progressively worse offers unless they read stubbornness on my side, so I’ll reject but also launch a more balanced counter-proposal that respects my relative scarcity of Ore.

I have Brick looking bulky (24). I need more Ore while maintaining balance.
I won’t yield more than 38 value per Ore, so my counter needs careful value-matching.

Proposed counter-offer

Give 3 Brick (3×29 = 87) → Receive 2 Ore (2×39 = 78)  
Net value change for me = 78 – 87 = –9  
slightly negative for me, but Brick surplus is big; 2 Ore is solid.

[Offer: 3 Brick -> 2 Ore]
